item.title: My_First_Game
item.description: This tutorial walks you through the very first steps that are needed to create your first game. If you have no experience with GameMaker, you should start here!

item.title: 01_Resources
item.description: Learn how to add new resources to your game.

item.title: 02_Movement
item.description: This tutorial shows how to do basic movement using Drag'n'Drop and code

item.title: 03_Collisions
item.description: Here we show you how to test for collisions between two instances

item.title: 04_Gameplay
item.description: In this tutorial we add some simple gameplay elements into a game to enhance the user experience.

item.title: 05_Sound
item.description: This tutorial shows how to add sound effects to a game.

item.title: 06_Animation
item.description: With this tutorial you can learn how to add animations to your sprites.

item.title: 07_Game_States
item.description: Here we show you how to add different "states" to your game, ie: Game Over, Level Complete etc...

item.title: 08_Levels_And_Saving
item.description: With this tutorial we show how you can add a level select system to your game as well as how to save this to a file.

item.title: 09_Advanced_Gameplay
item.description: Learn how to add power ups and other extras to your game.

item.title: 10_Monetisation
item.description: This tutorial explains how to add adverts to your game.

item.title: 11_Social_Gaming
item.description: Here we show you how to add Twitter and Facebook buttons to your game

item.title: 12_Polish
item.description: This tutorial takes an example game from previous tutorials and shows how to add extras to it to enhance the user experience.

item.title: Audio_Part1_Adding_Audio
item.description: This tutorial will show you how to add simple sound effects and a music track to your games, as well as explain the different options available for your imported audio files.

item.title: Audio_Part2_Changing_Audio
item.description: With this tutorial you will learn how to fade sounds, change their pitch and move them within the stereo field.

item.title: Basic_Isometric_Tutorial
item.description: A very simple tutorial to show how to get started creating an isometric style game.

item.title: Coding_BreakOut
item.description: With this tutorial you will learn how to make a simple "Breakout" game using only code. It introduces all the basics of learning to code with the GameMaker Language.

item.title: Particles
item.description: This tutorial takes you through all the possible methods for creating particles using Drag'n'Drop and code.

item.title: Physics_Basics_1
item.description: Part 1 in a 3-part beginners' guide to using physics. It is an introduction to uses physics and uses only the Object Editor and the Room Editor to create a very basic physics simulation.

item.title: Physics_Basics_2
item.description: Part 2 in a 3-part beginners' guide to using physics. It shows how to code physical properties as fixtures for instances, as well as how to bind multiple fixtures to get concave shapes and finally explores how to use impulses and forces to push instances around.

item.title: Physics_Basics_3
item.description: Part 3 in a 3-part beginners' guide to using physics. It shows how to code physics rooms, how to debug physics fixtures, and how to create joints between fixtures.

item.title: Scrolling_Shooter_Part1
item.description: This tutorial uses Drag And Drop to teach you how to make a basic scrolling shooter while investigating the core-concepts behind using GameMaker: Studio.

item.title: Scrolling_Shooter_Part2
item.description: Using a mix of Drag'n'Drop and simple code this tutorial expands upon the lessons learned for making a scrolling shooter (see the tutorial Scrolling Shooter Part 1).

item.title: Application_Surface_Overview
item.description: This tutorial explains what the application surface is and gives an overview of how it works.

item.title: 1945_Vs_Spy_Chase
item.description: In the case of this tutorial, we are going to take a "stripped down" version of a demo game that we made called "1945" and turn it into a new game called "Spy Chase". The basic game play will remain the same, ie: the player must move up the screen and shoot or avoid enemies, only in the new version we are going to have a car instead of a plane and a road instead of the open sea.

item.title: Angry_Cats_Vs_Angry_Castles
item.description: In the case of this tutorial, we are going to take a "stripped down" version of a demo game that we made called "Angry Cats" and turn it into a new game called "Angry Castles". The basic game play will remain the same, ie: The player must fire objects at different structures to win, however in "Angry Castles" we are going to use a canon instead of a catapult, and the canon balls are going to explode when they hit rather than just bounce off the walls.

item.title: Veg_Ninja_Vs_Duck_Shoot
item.description: In the case of this tutorial, we are going to take a "stripped down" version of a demo game that we made called "Veg Ninja" and turn it into a new game called "Duck Shoot". The basic game play will remain the same, i.e., objects enter the screen and the player has to destroy them, only in the new version we are going to have ducks instead of vegetables and the player will need to touch them rather than swipe over them.

item.title: HTML5_Scaling
item.description: This tutorial is an extension of the tutorials for the application surface and shows how to resize the HTML5 canvas element to suit different typoes of views and browser sizes.

item.title: Saving_And_Loading
item.description: This tutorial will show you different ways to save informations from your game to a file, as well as load the information again. This includes game states, key bindings and level data.

item.title: Scripting
item.description: Learn a bit about using scripts to control your gameplay. Shows what a script is, how to create one and explains a bit about why they are important.

item.title: Skeletal_Animation_With_Spine
item.description: This tutorial covers the basics of importing skeletal animation sprites made using the (external) program Spine and using them in your game.

item.title: Surfaces_Part1
item.description: With this tutorial you will learn how to use surfaces to create some basic special effects like shadows and decals.

item.title: Application_Surface_Scaling
item.description: Scaling your game to fit different windows and device displays can be complicated, so learn how to make it easier with this tutorial.

item.title: Analogue_Sticks
item.description: Learn how to configure on-screen analogue pads for touch devices using the GUI layer and custom scripts.

item.title: Pinch_And_Zoom
item.description: Here you can find out how to detect multiple touches on a device and use that to zoom or rotate an image or view.

item.title: Swipes
item.description: With this tutorial we show you how to detect swipes across a touch screen device.

item.title: URL_Encode_And_Twitter
item.description: This tutorial supplies a script for encoding URLs and shows how it can be applied to create a Twitter button in your games.

item.title: Vector_Sprites
item.description: This tutorial covers the basics of importing vector sprites using the SWF file format and using them in your game.

item.title: Virtual_Keys
item.description: This tutorial will show you how to add Virtual Keys to touch screen games.

item.title: Facebook_Connect
item.description: Here we show you how to set up your game to get the most from the built-in Facebook functions. It is for Android/iOS only and you will need a Facebook developers account.

item.title: GameCenter_Integration
item.description: This tutorial for iOS shows how to integrate basic Game Center functionality into your game. Note that although this is targeted at iOS, the functions are the same for Google Services and Amazon Game Circle.

item.title: Optimising_The_Draw_Pipeline
item.description: This short tutorial for Advanced users takes you through some of the most important optimisations that can be done in your game to make rendering faster. The tutorial was designed for the OUYA platform, and low-end Android devices in particular, but most of the techniques shown can be applied to most platforms.

item.title: Physics_Part1_Fixtures
item.description: This tutorial gives a brief overview of the most common physics functions and shows how to use them to create an "Asteroids" style game.

item.title: Push_Notifications
item.description: This tutorial will take you through the steps for adding local Push Notifications to your Android and iOS games, as well as cover how to set up remote notifications too.

item.title: Surfaces_Part2
item.description: With this tutorial you will learn how to use surfaces to create some advanced special effects like full screen blurring.

item.title: Application_Surface_Special_Effects
item.description: This tutorial shows how the application surface can be used for transitions and special effects.
